acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since its 96-hour LC50 for medaka is 0.043 mg/L (Ministry of the Environment, 2002), the substance was classified into Category 1 for its acute toxicity.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Since its rat LD50 = approx. 300 mg/kg according to the DFG (1998), the substance was classified into Category 3.

carcinogenicity.rationale: It is rated as "B2" by the EPA (U.S. EPA, 1991) and "R" by the NTP (U.S. NTP, 2005). Based on these ratings, the substance was classified into Category 2.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Its classification for acute toxicity is Category 1, it is not rapidly degradable (BIOWIN 2007), its potential for bioaccumulation is low (logPow = 2.94, SRC 2005), and NOEC is < 1 mg/L. Based on this information, the substance was classified into Category 1 for its chronic toxicity.

explosives.rationale: It contains chemical groups (hydrazine group) associated with explosive properties. Since no further information is available, classification is not possible.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

flammable_solids.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data. (it is reported to be combustible (ICSC))

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Both Ames test and in vitro chromosomal aberration test produced positive results (DFG (1998)). In addition, comet assay with mouse somatic cells gave positive results (RTECS (accessed in September 2007)). However, no test results in in-vivo mutagenicity studies are available, and the evaluation of the comet assay has not been finalized. As such, the substance was classified into the "Classification not possible" category.

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Organic compounds containing no oxygen, fluorine or chlorine

self_reactive_substances.rationale: It contains chemical groups (hydrazine group) associated with explosive properties. Since no further information is available, classification is not possible. (It belongs to Category V of hazardous materials: self-reactive substances, by the Fire Service Act.)

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: According to HSFS (1999), it can irritate the skin and eyes. However, since there is no clear evidence that supports this conclusion, the substance was classified into the "Classification not possible" category.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: According to HSFS (1999), it can irritate the skin and eyes. However, since there is no clear evidence that supports this conclusion, the substance was classified into the "Classification not possible" category.

skin_sensitizer.rationale: According to HSFS (1999), this substance may cause skin allergies, and if they progress, future re-exposure to even very low concentrations of this substance may cause itchiness and rash on the skin. However, since there is no clear evidence that supports this conclusion, the substance was classified into the "Classification not possible" category.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (liver)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: In an oral administration test using mice, necrosis of the liver was noted at doses that fall under the range of Category 2 guidance values (ATSDR (1990)). Thus, the substance was classified into Category 2 for the liver.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: According to HSFS (1999), swallowing this substance can irritate the nose and throat in humans. However, since there is no clear evidence that supports this conclusion, the substance was classified into the "Classification not possible" category.
